page.title: 07PEOPLE IN THE PAST-WENTHILLS
page.content: Although Wentbridge is now a quiet, sleepy little village, tucked away from the bustle of the A1, it has had an exciting past. In the seventeenth century, people who were trying to escape from the witch-hunters took refuge in nearby Brockadale. The most famous of these was Mary Pannal who was burned at the stake after being convicted at York in l603. Another well known character who lived in the area was the highwayman, Nevison. He stayed at the Gate Inn in Wentbridge and claimed protection money from travellers for giving them a safe passage between the Bluebell Inn, Wentbridge, and Ferrybridge. Nevison was the one who really made the ride from London to York, not Turpin. He escaped from his pursuers at Pontefract by taking a daring leap. He was caught and executed at York.
